issues.description: The template StockIngredient class exposes a quantity getter named retrieveQuantity(), but other code (template Stock, Main, and the problem statement expectation) use/getQuantity(). This is a signature/name mismatch for the quantity getter across artifacts and also contradicts the problem instruction to "add getters for all the private fields." As a result, the provided template does not compile as-is (Stock calls getQuantity()) and students will be blocked/confused when implementing SealSaloon or running the starter code.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the quantity getter consistent across artifacts. Update the template StockIngredient to provide public int getQuantity() (either rename retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity() or add getQuantity() delegating to retrieveQuantity()). This aligns with the problem instruction to add getters and matches Stock/Main usage and the solution implementation, preventing compilation errors and student confusion.

issues.description: The template uses a non-standard getter name retrieveQuantity() for StockIngredient, while the Stock implementation (in the template) and the solution use getQuantity(). The problem statement instructs to "add getters for all the private fields" (implying standard getter names). This mismatch creates a direct mapping and compilation confusion: template Stock calls getQuantity() but the template StockIngredient defines retrieveQuantity(), so students cannot easily map the required getter described in the problem to the actual method in the template and will encounter errors or extra cognitive overhead resolving which name to use.
issues.suggested_fix: Use the standard getter name getQuantity() for the quantity field in StockIngredient to align with the rest of the code and the problem statement. Concretely, rename retrieveQuantity() to getQuantity() in template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/StockIngredient.java (or add a getQuantity() method that delegates to retrieveQuantity()). This will align template, solution, and problem expectations and avoid compilation/mapping confusion.
